#Text=The first search engine was built by the " Centre Universitaire d'Informatique " of the University of Geneva .

column1: #Text=I predicted that search engines would not cope in the long term .
#Text=Maybe the existence of Google is only an indication that there is still only little available on the web .
#Text=You were at the inception of the WWW together with Tim Berners-Lee ; what aspects are you responsible for exactly ?
#Text=You 've convinced CERN to release the basic code library into the public domain ?
#Text=In 1990
#Text=I had already left programming for ten years and was doing management .
#Text=I 'm also 8 years older than Tim , who himself was no longer a young programmer .
#Text=It was evident that I could not compete with twenty year old Unix hackers and soon I stopped meddling with the writing of C code .
#Text=Anyway I know only one programming language worse than C and that is Javascript .
#Text=I did influence the shapes of the web and the directions of development , but I mainly occupied myself with obtaining the resources necessary to keep the project going .
#Text=I had a ( meager ) budget and so I got computers , offices , and above all people : young programmers who can spend a year working at CERN in the framework of its Technical Student Programme .
#Text=To get all that done I had to plead often with the management .
#Text=I also understood that CERN , as a lab for physics , would never devote a division to the web .

#Text=Therefore I began to contact true informatics institutes such as INRIA ( Institut national de recherche en informatique et en automatique , red . ) and FhG ( Fraunhofer Society , red . ) , as well as contacting the European Commission .
#Text=In this I was fortunately supported by Mike Sendall .
#Text=Mike , who was seen as neutral by CERN management , has done more than anyone else to help the development of the web inside CERN .
#Text=On the technical side it was not always the best of understanding between me and the team .
#Text=For example , I was convinced that we needed to build-in a programming language , but the developers , Tim first , were very much opposed .
#Text=It had to remain completely declarative .
#Text=Maybe , but the net result is that the programming-vacuum filled itself with the most horrible kluge in the history of computing : Javascript .
#Text=I also remember a big resistance against PostScript , but what do we see now ?
#Text=PDF everywhere .
#Text=Fortunately PDF is an open standard and it 's fairly elegant , but it could have turned out much worse .
#Text=SVG did not make it .

#Text=Tim , who had a longer experience with the internet world , convinced me that the web could only survive if all the code was freely available for everyone , [ ... ] put into the public domain . [ ... ]
#Text=The document was signed on 30 April 1993 that gave the WWW technology to the world .
